attributes.title: KONTRIBUSI KINERJA INDUSTRI BESAR DAN SEDANG PADA PEREKONOMIAN INDONESIA PERIODE 2013-2017
attributes.description: Industri memiliki peranan penting dalam pembangunan ekonomi di Indonesia. Setidaknya untuk siap menuju revolusi industri 4.0, Indonesia harus memiliki kemapanan dalam pembangunan industri dalam negeri melalui stabilitas ekonomi nasional terciptanya pertumbuhan ekonomi yang berkualitas. Penelitian ini menggunakan data seunder bersumber dari BPS dan Bank Indonesia. Metode penelitan yang digunakan dalah kuantitatif-deskriptif. Adapun hasil yang didapat adalah rata-rata pertumbuhan nilai output industri sedang dan besar di Indonesia adalah 23,4492% (dalam periode 2013-2017). Adapun melalui analisis regresi linear sederhana didapat persamaan Y ̂=7240389,66+0,425X_1, dengan korelasi yaitu 0,976. disamping itu guna mengukur faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output memiliki persamaan regresi yaitu Y ̂=17,712+31,197X_1-41,524X_2+7,375X_3, serta korelasi yaitu inflasi (0,735), suku bunga (0,140) dan UMR (0,298). Diharapkan, penulisan ini dapat menjadi gambaran bagi kontribusi kinerja industri besar dan sedang dalam pertumbuhan dan pembangunan ekonomi di Indonesia.

	Uji t (uji secara masing-masing variabel)
Pengujian yang dilakukan menggunakan signifikansi masing-masing variabel yang diuji terhadap variabel dependen. 
	Penyusunan hipotesis uji
	Ho : β=0, tidak memiliki pengaruh antara nilai output industri besar dan sedang terhadap PDB di Indonesia.
	Ha : β≠0, memiliki pengaruh antara nilai output industri besar dan sedang terhadap PDB di Indonesia.
	Daerah kritis dan tingkat signifikansi
t tabel = (t_(α/2),n-k) dimana α merupakan derajat signifikansi yaitu 5%, n adalah jumlah sampel yang diobservasi dan k adalah jumlah variabel bebas.
	Kriteria pengujian
Gambar 1. Daerah Uji t Hipotesis 1
 
	Ho tidak ditolak, apabila -t_tabelt_hitung hal ini dapat disimpulkan bahwa X_1 secara statistik berpengaruh terhadap Y pada tingkat α.
Cara lain untuk menguji signifikansi adalah dengan melihat nilai probabilitas, jika probabilitas <0,05 maka koefisien regresi itu memiliki signifikansi pada tingkat 5%.
	Pengujian Koefisien Determinasi (R^2)
Pengujian ini digunakan untuk mengetahui berapa % variasi variabel dependen dapat dijelaskan oleh variasi variabel independen. Dapat kita lakukan melalui perbandingan yaitu pengujian 0≤R^2≤1 dimana R^2 antara 0 dan 1, dan R^2 memiliki nilai positif. Apabila R^2 sebesar 1 berarti hubungan antara variabel dependen dan variabel independen bersifat sempurna, dan apabila R^2 memiliki nilai sebesar 0 maka tidak ada hubungan antara variabel dependen dengan variabel independen.

	Uji F (uji secara bersama-sama)
Digunakan untuk menguji signifikansi variabel  independen secara bersama-sama. Langkah-langkah yang dilakukan antara lain:
	Penyusunan hipotesis uji
	Ho : β_1=β_2=β_3=0, tidak ada pengaruh antara inflasi, suku bunga dan UMR rata-rata nasional terhadap nilai output industri besar dan sedang di Indonesia.

Pengujian ini digunakan untuk mengetahui berapa % variasi variabel dependen dapat dijelaskan oleh variasi variabel independen. Dapat kita lakukan melalui perbandingan yaitu pengujian 0≤R^2≤1 dimana R^2 antara 0 dan 1, dan R^2 memiliki nilai positif. Apabila R^2 sebesar 1 berarti hubungan antara variabel dependen dan variabel independen bersifat sempurna, dan apabila R^2 memiliki nilai sebesar 0 maka tidak ada hubungan antara variabel dependen dengan variabel independen.

Metode Analisis Data
Dalam mengetahui pengaruh dan kontribusi faktor-faktor tertentu terhadap variabel dependen dalam berbagai model maka digunakan dua analisis dan menggunakan dua model analisis yaitu sebagai beriku:
	Model Analisis Hipotesis 1
PDB=β_0+β_1 NOIP+ei	(3.1)
Dengan keterangan:
PDB	=	Produk Domestik Bruto
β_0 	=	Konstanta
NOIP	=	Nilai Output Industri Pengolahan
β_1 	=	Koefisien regresi masing-masing variabel, merupakan elastisitas terhadap nilai outputs
ei	=	Varibel pengganggu
	Model Analisis Hipotesis 2
NOIP=β_0+β_1 INF 〖+ β〗_1 SB+β_1 UMR+ei	(3.2)
Dengan keterangan:
NOIP	=	Nilai Output Industri Pengolahan
β_0 	=	Konstanta
INF	=	Inflasi
SB	=	Suku Bunga
UMR	=	Upah Minimum Regional
β_1 	=	Koefisien regresi masing-masing variabel, merupakan elastisitas terhadap nilai outputs
ei	=	Varibel pengganggu
Adapun metode yang diguanakn adalah menggunakan estimasi parameter dengan fungsi regresi linear sederhana  (untuk persamaan 3.1) dan menggunakan regresi linear berganda (untuk persamaan 3.2). maka bila asumsi klasik terpenuhi dengan diperolehnya OLS dalam bentuk BLUE (best linear unbiased estimator).

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q9.value: Metode penelitian yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah metode kuantitatif, dengan menggunakan analisis pertumbuhan sektor industri besar dan sedang dan melakukan perhitungan untuk perubahan nilai input, tambah dan output dan nilai rata-rata perubahan dari tahun 2013-2017. Disamping itu menggunakan analisis regresi linear berganda untuk menjelaskan faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan kecil, yaitu menggunakan data tingkat inflasi, suku bunga acuan BI dan UMR rata-rata nasional. Adapun data yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah data sekunder dengan menggunakan data nilai input, nilai tambah dan nilai outputs industri besar dan sedang Indonesia dari tahun 2013-2017 serta data mengenai nilai Produk Domestik Bruto Indonesia pada tahun 2013-2017. Disamping itu untuk melihat faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan sedang digunakan data inflasi 2013-2017 bersumber dari BPS, suku bungan BI-Rate tahun 2013-2015 dan suku bungan BI-7 Days Repo Rate untuk tahun 2016-2017 serta data UMR rata-rata nasional bersumber dari BPS.

Disamping itu menggunakan analisis regresi linear berganda untuk menjelaskan faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan kecil, yaitu menggunakan data tingkat inflasi, suku bunga acuan BI dan UMR rata-rata nasional. Adapun data yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah data sekunder dengan menggunakan data nilai input, nilai tambah dan nilai outputs industri besar dan sedang Indonesia dari tahun 2013-2017 serta data mengenai nilai Produk Domestik Bruto Indonesia pada tahun 2013-2017. Disamping itu untuk melihat faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan sedang digunakan data inflasi 2013-2017 bersumber dari BPS, suku bungan BI-Rate tahun 2013-2015 dan suku bungan BI-7 Days Repo Rate untuk tahun 2016-2017 serta data UMR rata-rata nasional bersumber dari BPS.

Produk Domestik Bruto
Nilai Output Industri Besar dan Sedang
Inflasi
Suku Bunga
UMR Rata-Rata Nasional

1.	Pertambahan Nilai Output Industri Besar dan Sedang
Pertambahan nilai output adalah jumlah presentase perubahan tahun sekarang dengan tahun sebelumnya dalam output nilai pada industri besar dan sedang. Dalam hal ini menggunakan data bersumber dari BPS, untuk hipotesis 1 menggunakan nilai mutlak pada nilai output industri besar dan sedang, sedangkan untuk hipotesis 2 menggunakan presentase perubahan nilai output dalam bentuk persen (%).
2.	Pertumbuhan Ekonomi (Economic Growth)/ Produk Domestik Bruto (PDB)
Pertumbuhan ekonomi adalah pertambahan nilai output sektor-sektor ekonomi secara nasional. Dalam hal ini digunakan Produk Domestik Bruto Indonesia periode tahun 2009-2018. Sumber yang digunakan adalah data Produk Domestik Brtuo Indonesia Menurut Lapangan Usaha berdasarkan Harga Konstan 2010 bersumber dari Badan Pusat Statistik. Diolah terlebih dahulu menjadi pertumbuhan dalam persen (%).
3.	Suku Bunga
Suku Bunga adalah Harga uang dalam tansaksi jual beli. Dalam analisis ini menggunakan BI Rate untuk rentang waktu 2009-2015 dan menggunakan BI 7 Day Repo Rate pada rentang waktu 2016-2018. Adapun data berbentuk persen (%).
4.	Inflasi
Inflasi adalah kenaikan harga barang-barang yang bersifat umum dan terus menerus. Data bersumber dari Badan Pusat Statistik dan diolah kembali untuk membentuk persentase perubahan dalam bentuk persen (%)
5.	Rata-Rata UMR Nasional
UMR atau Upah Minimum Regional adalah peraturan yang dikeluarkan pemerintah untuk menetapkan upah minimum yang menjadi batas dalam pemberian upah pada pekerja yang berlaku pada regional/kawasan tertentu. Dalam analisis ini menggunakan rata-rata UMR nasional dengan mencari rata-rata dari jumlah UMR 34 provinsi di Indonesia, data dalam bentuk presentase perubahan persen (%).

Metode Analisis Data

Dalam mengetahui pengaruh dan kontribusi faktor-faktor tertentu terhadap variabel dependen dalam berbagai model maka digunakan dua analisis dan menggunakan dua model analisis yaitu sebagai beriku:

	Model Analisis Hipotesis 2

Metode Analisis Data
Dalam mengetahui pengaruh dan kontribusi faktor-faktor tertentu terhadap variabel dependen dalam berbagai model maka digunakan dua analisis dan menggunakan dua model analisis yaitu sebagai beriku:
	Model Analisis Hipotesis 1
PDB=β_0+β_1 NOIP+ei	(3.1)
Dengan keterangan:
PDB	=	Produk Domestik Bruto
β_0 	=	Konstanta
NOIP	=	Nilai Output Industri Pengolahan
β_1 	=	Koefisien regresi masing-masing variabel, merupakan elastisitas terhadap nilai outputs
ei	=	Varibel pengganggu
	Model Analisis Hipotesis 2
NOIP=β_0+β_1 INF 〖+ β〗_1 SB+β_1 UMR+ei	(3.2)
Dengan keterangan:
NOIP	=	Nilai Output Industri Pengolahan
β_0 	=	Konstanta
INF	=	Inflasi
SB	=	Suku Bunga
UMR	=	Upah Minimum Regional
β_1 	=	Koefisien regresi masing-masing variabel, merupakan elastisitas terhadap nilai outputs
ei	=	Varibel pengganggu
Adapun metode yang diguanakn adalah menggunakan estimasi parameter dengan fungsi regresi linear sederhana  (untuk persamaan 3.1) dan menggunakan regresi linear berganda (untuk persamaan 3.2). maka bila asumsi klasik terpenuhi dengan diperolehnya OLS dalam bentuk BLUE (best linear unbiased estimator).
registration_responses.q10.question: Metode penelitian yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah metode kuantitatif, dengan menggunakan analisis pertumbuhan sektor industri besar dan sedang dan melakukan perhitungan untuk perubahan nilai input, tambah dan output dan nilai rata-rata perubahan dari tahun 2013-2017. Disamping itu menggunakan analisis regresi linear berganda untuk menjelaskan faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan kecil, yaitu menggunakan data tingkat inflasi, suku bunga acuan BI dan UMR rata-rata nasional. Adapun data yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah data sekunder dengan menggunakan data nilai input, nilai tambah dan nilai outputs industri besar dan sedang Indonesia dari tahun 2013-2017 serta data mengenai nilai Produk Domestik Bruto Indonesia pada tahun 2013-2017. Disamping itu untuk melihat faktor-faktor yang mempengaruhi nilai output industri besar dan sedang digunakan data inflasi 2013-2017 bersumber dari BPS, suku bungan BI-Rate tahun 2013-2015 dan suku bungan BI-7 Days Repo Rate untuk tahun 2016-2017 serta data UMR rata-rata nasional bersumber dari BPS.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Produk Domestik Bruto
Nilai Output Industri Besar dan Sedang
Inflasi
Suku Bunga
UMR Rata-Rata Nasional
registration_responses.q15.question:
1.	Pertambahan Nilai Output Industri Besar dan Sedang
Pertambahan nilai output adalah jumlah presentase perubahan tahun sekarang dengan tahun sebelumnya dalam output nilai pada industri besar dan sedang. Dalam hal ini menggunakan data bersumber dari BPS, untuk hipotesis 1 menggunakan nilai mutlak pada nilai output industri besar dan sedang, sedangkan untuk hipotesis 2 menggunakan presentase perubahan nilai output dalam bentuk persen (%).
2.	Pertumbuhan Ekonomi (Economic Growth)/ Produk Domestik Bruto (PDB)
Pertumbuhan ekonomi adalah pertambahan nilai output sektor-sektor ekonomi secara nasional. Dalam hal ini digunakan Produk Domestik Bruto Indonesia periode tahun 2009-2018. Sumber yang digunakan adalah data Produk Domestik Brtuo Indonesia Menurut Lapangan Usaha berdasarkan Harga Konstan 2010 bersumber dari Badan Pusat Statistik. Diolah terlebih dahulu menjadi pertumbuhan dalam persen (%).
3.	Suku Bunga
Suku Bunga adalah Harga uang dalam tansaksi jual beli. Dalam analisis ini menggunakan BI Rate untuk rentang waktu 2009-2015 dan menggunakan BI 7 Day Repo Rate pada rentang waktu 2016-2018. Adapun data berbentuk persen (%).
4.	Inflasi
Inflasi adalah kenaikan harga barang-barang yang bersifat umum dan terus menerus. Data bersumber dari Badan Pusat Statistik dan diolah kembali untuk membentuk persentase perubahan dalam bentuk persen (%)
5.	Rata-Rata UMR Nasional
UMR atau Upah Minimum Regional adalah peraturan yang dikeluarkan pemerintah untuk menetapkan upah minimum yang menjadi batas dalam pemberian upah pada pekerja yang berlaku pada regional/kawasan tertentu. Dalam analisis ini menggunakan rata-rata UMR nasional dengan mencari rata-rata dari jumlah UMR 34 provinsi di Indonesia, data dalam bentuk presentase perubahan persen (%).

	Pengujian Hipotesis 1
	Uji t (uji secara masing-masing variabel)
Pengujian yang dilakukan menggunakan signifikansi masing-masing variabel yang diuji terhadap variabel dependen. 
	Penyusunan hipotesis uji
	Ho : β=0, tidak memiliki pengaruh antara nilai output industri besar dan sedang terhadap PDB di Indonesia.
	Ha : β≠0, memiliki pengaruh antara nilai output industri besar dan sedang terhadap PDB di Indonesia.
	Daerah kritis dan tingkat signifikansi
t tabel = (t_(α/2),n-k) dimana α merupakan derajat signifikansi yaitu 5%, n adalah jumlah sampel yang diobservasi dan k adalah jumlah variabel bebas.
	Kriteria pengujian
Gambar 1. Daerah Uji t Hipotesis 1
 
	Ho tidak ditolak, apabila -t_tabelt_hitung hal ini dapat disimpulkan bahwa X_1 secara statistik berpengaruh terhadap Y pada tingkat α.
Cara lain untuk menguji signifikansi adalah dengan melihat nilai probabilitas, jika probabilitas <0,05 maka koefisien regresi itu memiliki signifikansi pada tingkat 5%.
	Pengujian Koefisien Determinasi (R^2)
Pengujian ini digunakan untuk mengetahui berapa % variasi variabel dependen dapat dijelaskan oleh variasi variabel independen. Dapat kita lakukan melalui perbandingan yaitu pengujian 0≤R^2≤1 dimana R^2 antara 0 dan 1, dan R^2 memiliki nilai positif. Apabila R^2 sebesar 1 berarti hubungan antara variabel dependen dan variabel independen bersifat sempurna, dan apabila R^2 memiliki nilai sebesar 0 maka tidak ada hubungan antara variabel dependen dengan variabel independen.
	Pengujian Hipotesis 2
	Uji Statistik
	Uji t (uji secara masing-masing variabel)

	Ha : β≠0, memiliki pengaruh antara nilai output industri besar dan sedang terhadap PDB di Indonesia.

t tabel = (t_(α/2),n-k) dimana α merupakan derajat signifikansi yaitu 5%, n adalah jumlah sampel yang diobservasi dan k adalah jumlah variabel bebas.
	Kriteria pengujian
Gambar 2. Daerah Uji t Hipotesis 2
 
Sumber: Dokumen Penulis
	Ho tidak ditolak, apabila -t_tabelt_hitung hal ini dapat disimpulkan bahwa X_1 secara statistik berpengaruh terhadap Y pada tingkat α.
Cara lain untuk menguji signifikansi adalah dengan melihat nilai probabilitas, jika probabilitas <0,05 maka koefisien regresi itu memiliki signifikansi pada tingkat 5%.
	Uji F (uji secara bersama-sama)
Digunakan untuk menguji signifikansi variabel  independen secara bersama-sama. Langkah-langkah yang dilakukan antara lain:
	Penyusunan hipotesis uji
	Ho : β_1=β_2=β_3=0, tidak ada pengaruh antara inflasi, suku bunga dan UMR rata-rata nasional terhadap nilai output industri besar dan sedang di Indonesia.
	Ho : β_1≠β_2≠β_3≠0, tidak ada pengaruh antara inflasi, suku bunga dan UMR rata-rata nasional terhadap nilai output industri besar dan sedang di Indonesia.

	Daerah kritis dan tingkat signifikansi
F tabel = F (α;(n-k),(k-1), dimana α merupakan derajat signifikansi (5%), n merupakan jumlah sampel yang diobservasi dan k merupakan variabel bebas.
	Kriteria pengujian
Gambar 3. Daerah Uji F
 
Sumber: Dokumen Penulis
	Ho tidak ditolak, apabila F hitung <  F tabel. Kesimpulannya dapat dikatakan bahwa semua koefisien regresi secara bersama-sama tidak signifikan pada tingkat α.
	Hot ditolak, apabila F hitung > F tabel. Kesimpulannya dapat dikatakan bahwa semua koefisien regresi secara bersama-sama signifikan pada tingkat α.

	Pengujian Koefisien Determinasi (R^2)
Pengujian ini digunakan untuk mengetahui berapa % variasi variabel dependen dapat dijelaskan oleh variasi variabel independen. Dapat kita lakukan melalui perbandingan yaitu pengujian 0≤R^2≤1 dimana R^2 antara 0 dan 1, dan R^2 memiliki nilai positif. Apabila R^2 sebesar 1 berarti hubungan antara variabel dependen dan variabel independen bersifat sempurna, dan apabila R^2 memiliki nilai sebesar 0 maka tidak ada hubungan antara variabel dependen dengan variabel independen.

attributes.title: Worst Motive Data and R script

item1.value: In Walmsley and O'Madagain "The Worst Motive Fallacy" we found that participants were significantly inclined to expect an agent in a story to act on the worst of two motives we described the agent as having. We want to replicate this in the following study.

item2.value:
In our replication, we will use 12 vignettes instead of just the 4 from our original study (we will replicate the effect of the 4, and add 8 more). This will increase the diversity of the vignettes, and also allow us to include vignette as a random effect in the model for the study (a random effect with four levels is not optimal). 

Also, the effect we found before was significant but not highly. If the effect is real, it should replicate.

item3.value: n/a. effects reported through model comparison

item4.value: n/a. effects reported through model comparison

item16.value: We are using three times as many stimuli as in the original, so we want to increase the sample size sufficiently to include vignette as a random effect, hence multiplying the sample size by 3.

item24.value: We are replicating the original four vignettes but also eight more, to increase the plausibility of our conclusion (that the effect is independent of the context). The additional vignettes may affect the outcome. We are also including vignette as a random effect in the model, which is a sound approach now that we have twelve vignettes - this may also affect the outcome.

item25.value: None. We have made the prediction that our effect is independent of context - therefore we should be able to find the effect across new vignettes with the same basic structure. If we pilot these vignettes to "see if they work", this would bias our selection of vignettes unreasonably in our favor.

item26.value:
Participants are given three very easy 'attention questions' at the outset of the study, and those who do not answer all three correctly are excluded on the assumption that they are not paying attention.
Participants who do not complete the study are excluded.

item27.value: Include random effect of vignette, whereas vignette was included as a fixed effect in our original study. The inclusion of vignette as a random effect is to take a more conservative approach to the claim that the effect is not dependent on the vignette chosen.

item28.value: The study will replicate successfully if, for the original vignettes as well as new vignettes with the same basic structure, participants significantly expect the agent in the vignette to act on the worst of two competing motives she has.

attributes.title: Outcome: Behavioral Responses
attributes.description: Personality and behavioral responses to the COVID-19 pandemic
tags: personality traits; COVID-19; behavioral responses; neuroticism; conscientiousness

q1.value: Damaris Aschwanden, Angelina Sutin, Antonio Terracciano, Martina Luchetti, Jason Strickhouser, Ji Hyun Lee, Amanda A. Sesker

q2.value:
We hypothesized that the FFM personality traits would be associated with psychological and behavioral responses related to the COVID-19 pandemic. More specifically:
1. We hypothesized that higher neuroticism would be linked to more concerns.
2. We hypothesized that individuals who score high on neuroticism or high on conscientiousness would take more precautions to avoid catching the coronavirus.
3. We hypothesized that higher neuroticism and higher conscientiousness would be positively associated with pandemic-related preparatory behaviors. 
4. We hypothesized that higher neuroticism would be linked to more pessimistic estimates on the duration of pandemic-related issues and higher extraversion was hypothesized to predict more optimistic responses regarding these duration estimates.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Prospective cohort study: Do personality traits at pretest (in January/February 2020) predict behavioral responses to the COVID-19 pandemic (posttest in March 2020)?

q7.value: Survey blocks will be randomized. After reporting demographic information, participants will either get the block with the personality measure first or the block with questions about their response to the coronavirus pandemic. All participants will complete all blocks. Qualtrics will randomize the order upon starting the survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: This project uses both existing data that has not yet been analyzed and data that are being collected now. The pretest data were collected between January 31, 2020 and February 10, 2020 and have not yet been analyzed. The pretest data collection was not preregistered. The data that are being collected now will be used as a posttest. This data collection started on March 18, 2020; is still ongoing, and has been preregistered as the following project: https://osf.io/vqnh8

question.value: NA (data have already been collected or are in the process of being collected)

q11.value: The sample size is based on the estimation of the preregistered data collection: It was expected that at least 40% of the original target of 3,500 participants (N=1,400) would complete the survey.

q12.value: The sample size is based on the existing data (pretest) and ongoing data collection that will serve as posttest.

q13.value: The population is a fixed cohort and the aim is to test as many participants as possible from this fixed cohort.

question.value: NA

Personality traits at pretest will be scored as indicated by the scoring system for the scales (i.e., items will be reverse scored when necessary in the direction of the trait label and the mean taken across items).

Precautions and preparatory behaviors at posttest will be scored as yes=1 or no=0 and summed across items. For concerns and duration estimates (answered on a Likert-type scale), the mean will be taken across items.

For the main analyses, we will use the sum of precautions and preparatory behaviors and the average of concern and estimates of duration as outcomes. Multiple regression analyses will be completed to analyze the association between personality traits and these outcomes. For each personality trait, a separate model will be run. In a follow-up model, all five factors will be added simultaneously. These models will be:

Model 1: outcome scale ~ covariates 
Model 2: outcome scale ~ personality trait + covariates

For supplementary analyses, we will further analyze the set of outcomes based on their individual items as there might be differences in the predictive power of personality traits and various behavioral responses. For concerns (13 items; see “Posttest Survey March 2020”), we will run a factor analysis in order to identify potential clusters. The clusters will then be used for further analysis. For precautions, 6 items (see “measured variables”) will be analyzed. For preparatory behaviors, 5 items (see “measured variables”) will be analyzed. For estimates of duration, 5 items (see “measured variables”) will be analyzed. Binary logistic regression analyses will be completed to analyze the association between personality traits and the individual outcomes that have yes/no responses. For each personality trait, a separate model will be run. In a follow-up model, all five factors will be added simultaneously.

q18.value: Continuous covariates will be z-scored and interpreted in standard deviation units. Binary covariates will be coded into 1’s and 0’s.

q19.value: We use an alpha level of .05 as our criterion for statistical significance.

q20.value: Participants who show evidence of careless responding (e.g., demographics do not match across the pre- and posttest) or straight lining (i.e., giving the same answer across the personality inventory) will be excluded. Participants who tested positive for the coronavirus will be excluded since the focus of the present work is on individuals who are at-risk of catching the virus.

q21.value: Participants with missing data on personality (>20% of personality items) will be excluded from all data analysis. Additionally, participants with missing data on a particular outcome scale (>20% of items) will be excluded from analyses of that outcome.

q22.value: In a series of exploratory analyses, we will (a) test whether age moderated the associations between personality and behavioral responses and (b) consider the possible interaction between personality traits (e.g., interaction between neuroticism and conscientiousness). To create the interaction terms, the standardized values will be multiplied.

attributes.title: Clinical efficacy and safety of somatostatin in the treatment of early postoperative inflammatory small bowel obstruction: A protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: Early postoperative inflammatory small bowel obstruction (EPISBO), a very common complication following colorectal operation, often occurs in the early stage after abdominal operation (within 2 to 3 weeks). The primary cause of EPISBO is a kind of mechanical and dynamic abdominal adhesion of the intestinal tract due to wall edema and exudation because of injury of abdominal operation and post-operative abdominal inflammation, but intestinal strangulation rarely occurs. EPISBO occurs in the early stage after operation, and the major symptom is abdominal distension with or without mild abdominal pain. Adnominal inflammation-induced intensive intestinal adhesion is the major cause of the disease.Somatostatin was extracted from hypothalamus by Brazeau et al. in 1973 for the first time. Its full name is growth hormone-inhibiting hormone, a kind of cyclic peptide hormone consisting of 14 amino acids. It is widely distributed in pancreatic D cells and gastrointestinal autonomic nerves and can obviously inhibit the secretion of digestive juice in the gastrointestinal tract. Studies have shown that SS is used in treating EPISBO as it can significantly reduce the accumulation of digestive juice in intestinal canal above the obstructed segment, reduce dilatation and ischemia of intestine due to the accumulation of a large amount of fluid, accelerate the recovery of intestinal wall blood circulation and promote inflammation resolution. In order to explore the effectiveness and efficacy of SS as one of conservative therapy in treating EPISBO, we carried out a systematic review and a meta-analysis of the included randomized controlled trials so as to assess its effectiveness and efficacy in an objective manner.

q1.value: Ming Lin, Zhongyong Wu, Suibiao Wang, Shaofei Yuan

q2.value:
1. Somatostatin is an effective and safe method in the treatment of early postoperative inflammatory small bowel obstruction.
2. How does the efficacy of somatostatin compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with treatment efficacy in studies of somatostatin for patients with early postoperative inflammatory small bowel obstruction.

question.value:
1. Searches: The selection procedure for this meta-analysis was performed in strict accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA). Computer-based retrieval was conducted in the CNKI, WanFang Data, Sino Med, VIP, PubMed, Cochrane Library and Embase databases to collect all relevant published experimental studies in Chinese and English from the date of database creation through August 1, 2018 and to follow up with the references of the studies included. Regardless of the major result or language, all possibly qualified studies were considered for review.
2. Participants/population: EPISBO patients undergoing abdominal surgery, regardless of surgical type or surgical method, were included. Patient data were collected without limiting by age, gender or case source. The diagnostic criteria refer to the diagnostic criteria for early inflammatory bowel obstruction in the literature. 
3. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Experimental group: somatostatin combined with conventional treatment (not limited by dosage, times of administration, course of disease, interval of medication, or course of treatment).
4. Comparator(s)/control: Conventional treatment (not limited by dosage, times of administration, course of disease, interval of medication, or course of treatment).
5. Types of study to be included: Blinded or non-blinded studies on randomized controlled trials of somatostatin for the treatment of EPISBO in Chinese or English were included.
6. Data extraction (selection and coding): Two evaluators read document titles and abstracts independently and read through them when necessary. Any document on which the two evaluators has different opinions were discussed by the third evaluator to decide whether to include it. q11.value:
1. Participants/population: EPISBO patients undergoing abdominal surgery, regardless of surgical type or surgical method, were included. Patient data were collected without limiting by age, gender or case source. The diagnostic criteria refer to the diagnostic criteria for early inflammatory bowel obstruction in the literature.
2. Inclusion criteria: (1) There is a recent (within 1~3 weeks) history of abdominal surgery, especially a recent history of repeated surgeries and extensive separation of adhesions. (2) The peristalsis of all patients recovered at one time, but some patients had been discharged and had a bowel movement and developed intestinal obstruction symptoms 3~7 days later. (3) Abdominal X-ray showed many gas-liquid planes or intestinal pneumatosis; abdominal CT showed intestinal wall thickening, edema, adhesions, intestinal effusion and pneumatosis of peritoneal exudate. (4) In addition to external hernia, volvulus and anastomotic stenosis caused by factors such as mechanical intestinal obstruction; in addition to external causes of hypokalemia, visceral nerve injury and tumor metastasis caused by intestinal obstruction.
3. Exclusion Criteria: (1) Non- RCT documents; (2) Medicines not related to this research; (3) Patients whose baseline data were obviously inconsistent; (4) Patients whose inflammatory intestinal obstruction did not occur following abdominal surgery; (5) Case reports, reviews, animal experiments or important data reports are incomplete but the author does not give a reply; (6) The clinical outcomes included in the research do not involve those clinical outcome we wanted to assess.
4. Types of study to be included: Blinded or non-blinded studies on randomized controlled trials of somatostatin for the treatment of EPISBO in Chinese or English were included.

question.value: Statistical software Stata12.0 was used to conduct a meta-analysis of the data collected. Enumeration data were expressed in risk ratio (RR) and continuous variable were expressed in weighted mean difference (WMD) (both confidence interval were 95%). Heterogeneity test (Q test) was conducted on each experimental result. P>0.1 was considered to suggest no heterogeneity; P≤0.1 was considered to reveal   heterogeneity. The degree of heterogeneity was expressed by Higgins I2 (I2=(Q-df)/Q). If there was statistical homogeneity between various research results (P>0.1, I2≤50%), meta-analysis was conducted by using the fixed effect model; if there was statistical heterogeneity between various research results (P≤0.1, I2>50%), meta-analysis was conducted by using the random effects model after eliminating the effect of obvious clinical heterogeneity. Subgroup analysis or sensitivity analysis was performed to process obvious clinical heterogeneity, or only descriptive analysis was provided.

attributes.title: The Role of Cultural Capital in College and University Admissions Practices: An Audit Study
attributes.description: We are examining whether signals of cultural capital (e.g., tastes in music and leisure activities) influence interactions with key gatekeepers to social mobility--college and university admissions counselors. We explored this question in the context of an audit study in which we sent emails to admissions counselors at colleges and universities around the country, ostensibly from a high school student interesting in applying. Counselors were randomly assigned to receive one of two versions of the email. In the lowbrow condition, the email referenced extracurricular activities associated with lower-class cultural capital (e.g., action films, pick-up soccer), and in the highbrow condition, the email referenced extracurricular activities associated with upper-class cultural capital (e.g., independent films, skiing). The perceived gender of the student was also manipulated. We hypothesize that counselors will be more likely to respond, and will respond more positively, when the student is expressing highbrow tastes compared to when they are expressing lowbrow tastes.

q2.value: We hypothesize that counselors will be more likely to respond, and will respond more positively, when the student is expressing highbrow tastes compared to when they are expressing lowbrow tastes.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q5.value: We will make an effort to keep raters who will be recording and coding email responses from counselors blind to experimental condition. However, in some cases this will not be possible due to the presence of mentions of experimental content in the participants' replies. Coders will not, however, be informed as to the purpose of the study or any hypotheses.

question.value:
In this study, we sent emails to admissions counselors from colleges and universities around the country (one at each institution in our list), ostensibly from a high school student interested in applying for undergraduate admissions (Thornhill, 2018). The perceived gender of the student was manipulated between subjects--counselors were randomly assigned to receive an email from a student with traditionally male name (Zach Lancaster) or a student with a female name (Jessica Huston). Most importantly perceived cultural capital was also manipulated between subjects by randomly assigning counselors to receive an email containing references to either highbrow or lowbrow extracurricular activities. The remainder of the content in the email will be held constant. The general text of the email will read as follows:

"My name is (student name) and I am a high school junior in the San Francisco Bay Area. I will be applying to colleges next Fall. The career counselor at my high school recommended that I look into (college). I am interested in potentially majoring in sociology or another social science. I have also participated in many extracurricular activities during my time in high school, including writing for the school newspaper and volunteering at a local animal shelter. (manipulated content). I hope to continue to my involvement in these activities while in college. I just wanted to reach out to see if opportunities were available at (college) to pursue these interests, and whether you think I would be a good fit."

In the lowbrow condition, the manipulated content will read: "I also play on the school basketball team and enjoy playing pick-up soccer. Finally, I play guitar in a rock band at school and am president of the action movie club."

In the highbrow condition, this content read: "I also play trombone in a symphonic band at school and am president of the independent film club. Finally, I play on the school tennis team and enjoy going skiing in the winter."

Our primary outcome measure in this study will be admissions counselor response rates. However, among those who do respond, we will code for the level of positivity in the response.

q7.value: We will use simple randomization in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two cultural capital conditions and one of two gender conditions. Randomization will be determined by creating a list of randomly generated numbers (1s and 2s) in an Excel spreadsheet.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: Data regarding all independent variables and covariates (i.e., characteristics of all colleges/universities and admissions counselors in the sample) were compiled from publicly available datasets and websites prior to emails being sent. As of this moment, the emails have been sent and all replies are currently in our study email inboxes. No individuals, including those on the research team, have examined the email replies in any way.

question.value: We emailed a total of 973 admissions counselors, one at each institution in our list. Counselors were not compensated in any way for their participation and in fact were never informed that they were in a psychological study (per CPHS request). We obtained our sample of colleges and universities from a publicly available dataset compiled by Opportunity Insights—a policy-oriented research institute—for a study on the role of colleges in intergenerational mobility (Chetty, Friedman, Saez, Turner, & Yagan, 2017). This data file contains every higher education institution in the U.S., along with economic characteristics of each school (e.g., median income of students, percentage of parents in different income quintiles). We filtered our list to only include selective and highly selective public and private colleges and universities; all other college tiers were not included (e.g., community colleges, for-profit colleges). This yielded a total of 1,130 institutions. We then instructed research assistants to navigate to each institution’s admissions website and pick an admissions counselor to contact. Given that our emails will be ostensibly sent by a high school student from the San Francisco Bay Area, when possible, we selected admissions counselors whose territory included this area. If counselors were not assigned a territory, our assistants selected one at random. Schools with no admissions counselors listed on the website (i.e., only a general email was included) were excluded from our sample for consistency, thus resulting in a final sample of 973 counselors (658 from private institutions, 315 from public institutions). Data on the racial makeup of each university’s undergraduate population (to be included as covariates in our analyses) were collected from the National Center for Education Statistics’ Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS).

q12.value: This number represents all colleges/universities in the United States which meet the following the criteria: 1) they are selective or highly selective, 2) they do not orient admission towards specific demographic groups (e.g., they are not gendered or historically black colleges/universities), 3) they offer a broad range of majors/areas of study (e.g., they are not art schools or other speciality schools), and 4) the school's website offered a list of admissions counselors who had email addresses that were publicly available.

question.value: The perceived gender of the student was manipulated between subjects--counselors were randomly assigned to receive an email from a student with traditionally male name (Zach Lancaster) or a student with a female name (Jessica Huston). Most importantly perceived cultural capital was also manipulated between subjects by randomly assigning counselors to receive an email containing references to either highbrow or lowbrow extracurricular activities.

The primary outcome variables are whether or not the counselor responded to our email and, among the responses that were received, how positive was the tone of the email. The latter measure will be created by having two independent coders rate each email responses on a scale from 1 (not at all positive) to 4 (very positive).

Our data will be analyzed using multiple logistic (binary response variable) and linear (response positivity scale) regression models. In these models, we will examine the effect of cultural capital condition, perceived gender of the interested student, and the median income of the students' families at each institution, as well as the interactions between these variables. We will also run analyses without and with covariates related to characteristics of the counselors (e.g., gender, perceived age/race) and institutions (e.g., % of non-White students, private/public) in a stepwise fashion (all analyses will be reported).

q20.value: All sent emails will be included in the final dataset except those for which we receive a response from an admissions counselor who was not the intended recipient of the email (e.g., due to the intended recipient no longer working in the admissions office).

q22.value: We do intend to explore possible moderators of the hypothesized main effect of cultural capital on email responses. Most importantly, we will explore the moderating role of economic factors such as the median family income of students at the university, the percentage of the university's undergraduate population in the top quintile of incomes in the U.S., and the sticker price of admission. We will also explore factors such as perceived age and race of the counselor, the gender of the fake student sending the email, and other characteristics of the university (e.g., private/public).

attributes.title: The Availability of Essential Cancer Medicines in Low-Middle-Income Countries: A systematic Review

summary.value: The right to health should be understood as a human right concern and hence is the responsibility of every country to ensure access to medicines for its citizens.  The availability of essential cancer medicines (ECMs) is part of the fulfillment of this human right. So why do masses of cancer patients in LMICs go without the treatment they need? This review is finding out the availability of ECMs in LMICs and the reasons if they are not available.

This review is finding out the availability of ECMs in LMICs and the reasons if they are not available.

attributes.title: PSYC 2017 - Internet Trolling
attributes.description: This study is analyzing whether or not personality traits from the Dark Tetrad can be correlated with online trolling behaviors.

q1.value: Dark Tetrad and its correlations with trolling

q2.value: Jonathan Holder, Amber N Hornsby, Kourtney Campo, Sterling Foster

q4.value: The Dark Tetrad will positively correlate with trolling and cyber bullying behaviors; extraversion and agreeableness to have associations with trolling. We also anticipate there to be a negative correlation between empathy and trolling/cyber bullying.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Correlational Study:
The study consists of 200 participants recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk website and is a repeated measures, within-subjects design study. The participants are asked to pick a favorite activity and then asked to describe their level of enjoyment on a scale. There is no other group or sample being analyzed besides the 200 participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

attributes.title: Where are we going: Evaluating availability, price and affordability of essential cancer medicines in Ghana

summary.value: The increasing trend in mortality and prevalence of cancers in LMICs is a significant public health concern. Despite this, access to essential cancer medicines (ECMs) is a significant challenge in LMICs. In Ghana, the treatment of cancer is provided by both public and private hospitals. The majority of the population access care at the public hospital. There is limited information on availability, pricing, and affordability of ECMs at the most public hospital in the country, which this survey was evaluating.

attributes.title: Perceived Aggressiveness and Fighting Performance in Mixed-Martial-Arts-Fighters: A Direct Replication of the Trebický et al. (2013) Study.
attributes.description: Třebický, Havlíček, Roberts, Little, and Kleisner (2013) argued that humans have evolved the capability to accurately perceive cues of fighting ability and aggressiveness.  This accurate assessment of fighting ability and aggressiveness is important for decision making in physical contests (e.g., whether or not one should engage in combat).  In their paper, Třebický et al. reported that perceived aggressiveness predicted actual fighting success, and that perceived fighting ability was associated with greater real-world fighting success. This finding was only observed amongst heavyweight fighters.  Třebický et al. is widely cited in the area of fighting ability and facial perception research. It has generated 65 citations on Google Scholar as of 6th April, 2020, yet there are potential methodological and statistical issues with their research.   To this end, an independent, pre-registered, direct replication will be conducted.

q1.value: Perceived Aggressiveness, Perceived Fighting Ability, and Fighting Performance in Mixed-Martial-Arts-Fighters: A Direct Replication and Extension of the Třebický et al. (2013) Study

q2.value: Neil Caton, Barnaby Dixson, Sam Pearson

q3.value:
Třebický, Havlíček, Roberts, Little, and Kleisner (2013) argued that humans have evolved the capability to accurately perceive cues of fighting ability and aggressiveness.  This accurate assessment of fighting ability and aggressiveness is important for decision making in physical contests (e.g., whether or not one should engage in combat).  In their paper, Třebický et al. reported that perceived aggressiveness predicted actual fighting success, and that perceived fighting ability was associated with greater real-world fighting success. This finding was only observed amongst heavyweight fighters.  Třebický et al. is widely cited in the area of fighting ability and facial perception research. It has generated 65 citations on Google Scholar as of 6th April, 2020, yet there are potential methodological and statistical issues with their research.   

Firstly, Třebický et al. reported that perceived fighting ability predicted actual fighting success only amongst heavyweight fighters (e.g., [pp. 1664 abstract], “In contrast, perception of fighting ability was confounded by weight, and an association between perceived fighting ability and actual fighting success was restricted to heavyweight fighters” and [pp. 1667 discussion], “Perceived fighting ability was predicted only by weight, and its link to fighting success was restricted to heavy-weights”).  However, Třebický et al. only “found a close-to-significant correlation between perceived fighting ability and fighting success in heavyweights (n = 33, r = .301, p = .088)” (pp. 1667).  This bivariate correlation was not below an alpha of .05—the widely accepted significance threshold for psychology (Benjamin et al., 2018)—and was their only statistical evidence for their claim that perceived fighting ability predicts real-world fighting success.

Furthermore, Třebický et al. argued that perceived aggressiveness is a sub-component of perceived fighting ability.  As they noted, “Fighting ability depends on many factors alongside aggression, so being seen as a powerful fighter does not necessarily equal being seen as aggressive.”  Given that perceived aggressiveness is overarched by perceived fighting ability, this suggests that perceived fighting ability was their most theoretically central variable.  Despite this, there was no empirical support for perceived fighting ability as a predictor of fighting success, and the positive relationship between fighting success and perceived aggressiveness (when controlling for weight) was arguably closely below the significance threshold (F(1, 143) = 4.91, p = .028, R2 = .033).

Second, geometric morphometric (GMM) analyses were not performed on perceived fighting ability.  Třebický et al. “searched for the specific facial traits associated with actual fighting ability and compared them with traits responsible for perceived aggressiveness” (pp. 1665) but did not examine the specific facial traits associated with perceived fighting ability, nor compared them to those associated with actual fighting ability.  It would seem most logical to compare traits associated with actual fighting ability with those associated with perceived fighting ability, especially as they “collected ratings of perceived fighting ability to test whether people are able to infer actual fighting ability” (pp. 1665).  While facial traits associated with heavyweight fighting success were examined, this does not mean that these traits were perceived as cues to fighting success (especially because perceived did not predict actual fighting ability).  Without examining the association between facial configuration and perceived fighting ability, it is unclear if there is consistent support for the hypothesis that humans can accurately perceive competitive ability from facial traits.  Thus, we will extend Třebický et al.’s analyses and examine the relationship between perceived fighting ability and facial structure—first in the overall sample, and then specifically for heavyweight fighters.

Third, several decisions made by Třebický et al regarding the inclusion and exclusion of certain MMA fighters are questionable.  Originally, the dataset comprised 336 MMA fighter portraits.  However, the final dataset comprised 146 photographs after the removal of portraits that contained a beard or moustache, hair that obscured the face, faces of perceivably African or Asian origin, or faces that were not directly faced into the camera.  There was no justification for these exclusion criteria reported by Třebický et al. in the paper.  While the presence of a beard might present difficulty in using geometric morphometric techniques (e.g., placing landmarks or semi-landmarks on the chin or jaw), it is unclear why fighters with a moustache were excluded.  It was also puzzling as to why Asian and African fighters were excluded, but not other non-Caucasian ethnic groups (e.g., Māori, and South, Central, and Native Americans).

Fourth, the study relied on an insufficient number of stimuli (i.e., face-based photographs of MMA fighters).  The final dataset comprised 146 photographs.  Thus, the paper’s two most important correlations (i.e., perceived aggressiveness [r = .203] and perceived fighting ability [r = .067] on fighting success) relied on this sample size, but these correlations in samples of this size are unstable and lack statistical power (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013).  Furthermore, the relation between facial shape and perceived aggressiveness in their overall sample was close to the significance threshold F(1, 143) = 1.97, p = .055, R2 = .013, suggesting that original study would benefit from a higher-powered design.  The original study would further benefit from a higher-powered design because, when controlling for weight, facial shape predicted perceived aggressiveness closely above (p = .055) and perceived aggressiveness predicted fighting success arguably closely below (p = .028) the significance threshold.

Despite the limited stimuli in the original sample, an even smaller sample was used when the analyses were conducted within each weight distribution.  The finding that perceived fighting ability and actual fighting success were “close-to-significant” (p = .088; pp. 1667) in heavyweight fighters relied on a collapsed sample of 19 light heavyweight and 14 heavyweight MMA fighters—overall, 33 “heavyweight” MMA fighters.  Furthermore, facial configuration predicted perceived aggressiveness (p = .037)—and similarly for facial configuration on actual fighting success (p = .033)—only in their limited sample of 33 heavyweights.  This study would benefit from a higher-powered design to more appropriately demonstrate the presence, or absence, of these associations.

Fifth, it was argued that, “raters might have primarily used cues of weight to attribute fighting ability” and therefore, should have also used cues of weight to attribute aggressiveness.  In support of this argument, their interaction between weight and perceived aggressiveness on fighting success was significant, leading them to state that this interaction “indicates that facial features responsible for attribution of aggressiveness are associated with weight distribution.”  Following up this interaction, they found that facial configuration did not predict perceived aggressiveness in their sample of lightweight MMA fighters, F(1, 60) = 1.78, p = .071, R2 = .029, but did in heavyweight fighters, F(1, 31) = 2.13, p = .037, R2 = .064, yielding support for their argument that facial shape predicts perceived aggressiveness in only heavyweight fighters.  While stated as non-significant, their relationship for facial shape and perceived aggressiveness in lightweight MMA fighters was closer to the significance threshold (p = .071) than their other (more central) hypothesised relationships (i.e., perceived fighting ability and fighting success in heavyweights was significant at p = .088).

For these reasons, it would be beneficial for the research to conduct a direct replication and extension of Třebický et al.’s (2013) seminal paper.

q4.value: In line with Třebický et al.’s a priori predictions, we hypothesise (H1) that perceived aggressiveness and perceived fighting ability would predict fighting success.  As per their post-hoc predictions, we hypothesise (H2) that perceived fighting ability would predict fighting success only in heavyweight fighters.  A limited sub-sample was used when the original study examined facial shape, and their significance rested closely below the significance threshold.  Thus, we hypothesise that these effects will be replicated such that (H3) facial shape would be associated with both perceived aggressiveness and fighting success only in heavyweight fighters.  Given the aforementioned unexplored analyses, we will extend the original study with a novel hypothesis (H4): facial shape will be associated with perceived fighting ability.  Following Třebický et al.’s analytical process, this relation will be tested in both the overall and heavyweight samples.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no blinding involved in this study.

question.value: Our current study will replicate the procedure employed by Trebicky et al. (2013), such that we have collected fight statistics and facial photographs from 734 MMA fighters from ufc.com and espn.com.  Seventy-one facial landmarks (including 36 semi-landmarks) will then be placed on these facial photographs, consistent with Kleisner, Kočnar, Rubešová, and Flegr (2010) (upon which Trebicky et al. (2013) was based, but excluding the uppermost facial landmark, which was also excluded in the current direct replication study).  Four-hundred US-based MTurk participants will then rate 50 out of 387 randomly-assigned faces on perceived aggressiveness and perceived fighting ability, and another 400 US-based MTurk participants these faces on perceived fighting ability.

q9.value: A total of 400 US-based MTurk participants will be randomly presented with, and rate, 50 out of 387 MMA fighter portraits for perceived aggressiveness.  Similarly, 400 US-based MTurk participants will be randomly presented with, and rate, 50 out of 387 MMA fighter portraits for perceived fighting ability.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value:
We have collected fight statistics and facial portraits of 734 MMA fighters, as retrieved from ufc.com and espn.com.  These statistics and portraits are available to anyone.  One research assistant has also coded these facial portraits regarding the presence/absence of a beard and/or moustache that is unsuitable for facial landmarking, whether they are facing directly into the camera, their ethnic origin (i.e., non-African/Asian, African, Asian), and whether the portraits featured hair that obscured the face.  Another independent research assistant coded these facial portraits on moustache and beardedness, to calculate reliability for beardedness (e.g., the frequency with which raters agreed).

After accounting for the exclusion criteria, there were 387 MMA fighters.  No data have been collected and finalised regarding the facial morphometrics, or participant ratings of perceived aggressiveness and fighting ability, which is the central focus of the replication.  Any patterns or summary statistics related to the replication cannot be observed without both the facial morphometric and participant rating data.

question.value:
We have collected fight statistics and facial portraits of 734 MMA fighters, as retrieved from ufc.com and espn.com.  These statistics and portraits are available to anyone.  One research assistant has also coded these facial portraits regarding the presence/absence of a beard and/or moustache, whether they are facing directly into the camera, their perceived ethnic origin (i.e., non-Asian/African, African, Asian), and whether the portraits featured hair that obscured the face.  We also excluded MMA fighters whose facial photographs were not available, and female fighters.  After the exclusion of all of these criteria, there were 387 MMA fighters.  

Seven research assistants will then place the facial landmarks on the facial portraits, with each research assistant landmarking approximately 102 faces.  This will take approximately two weeks.

A total of 400 US-based MTurk participants (that hold a 95% MTurk approval rating for completing at least 100 studies, and are at least 18 years old) will be randomly presented with, and rate, 50 out of 387 MMA fighter portraits for perceived aggressiveness.  Similarly, 400 US-based MTurk participants will be randomly presented with, and rate, 50 out of 387 MMA fighter portraits for perceived fighting ability.  These participants will be rewarded with $2.00 USD for this 15 minute study.  This will take approximately one week.

q13.value:
In the original study, 618 and 278 online Czech participants rated faces on perceived aggressiveness or perceived fighting ability, respectively, with each participant being randomly assigned 50 out of 146 faces.  This suggests that each face was rated for perceived aggressiveness 208.78 times (i.e., (618*50)/146 = 211.64) and for perceived fighting ability 93.92 times (278*50)/148 = 95.21).  There was no justification for this sample size in the original study, and this sample size may be unpragmatically large.  For this reason, we will instead recruit two separate samples of 400 US-based MTurk workers to rate 50 out of 387 randomly presented faces on either perceived fighting ability or aggressiveness, meaning that each face will be rated on these variables approximately 50 times (i.e., (400*50)/387 = 51.68).  We will then produce a graph documenting the rate of diminishing returns for reliability, to demonstrate that, as the amount of ratings increase up until a certain point, reliability does not improve, which will be done to counter potential arguments against our use of a smaller sample size of raters in our replication.

Fight statistics and facial portraits have been collected for all of the 734 MMA fighters on ufc.com and espn.com.  Consistent with the original study, we have removed female fighters, fighters with a beard or moustache that was unsuitable for facial landmarking, those of perceivably African or Asian origin, those not facing directly into the camera, and those whose face is obscured by their hair.  This has left us with a total of 387 MMA fighters.

q14.value: As we our constrained by the amount of MMA fighters who are competing, or have competed, in the UFC, we have collected data from all possible MMA fighters on ufc.com.  Our sample size rationale for MTurk participants is as above.  A sample size of above 250 allows stable estimates for our correlations (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013) and a sample size that is 2.5 times larger than the original study is a widely-cited guideline for direct replication research (Simonsohn, 2015).

q15.value: Our sample size for MMA fighters is stopped at all the available fighters competing, or those who have competed, in the UFC.  For participant raters, MTurk will essentially provide full control over our sample, thus data collection will be stopped at 400 participants (for the four separate samples).

question.value: No variables will be manipulated, as it is an observational study.

As per the original study, we will ask participants to rate the aggressiveness of the depicted person using a 7-point scale (from 1, not aggressive at all, to 7, very aggressive) and whether the depicted person is a good fighter (from 1, not at all, to 7, excellent).  Each participant’s ratings will be converted to z scores to account for differences in scale use, and a mean standardized score will be calculated for each photograph.

Fighting success will be calculated as the total number of wins relative to the proportion of fights (i.e., total wins divided by total numbers of fights), as per the original article.  Weight category, weight (in lbs) and fighter’s age is drawn from the ufc.com website.  There are eight categories for male fighters in the UFC: flyweight (up to 56.7kg), bantamweight (up to 61.2kg), featherweight (up to 65.8kg), lightweight (up to 70.3kg); welterweight (up to 77.1kg), middleweight (up to 83.9kg); light heavyweight (up to 93.0kg), and heavyweight (up to 120.2kg).  Similar to the original study, we will combine flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight and lightweight divisions into one category called "lightweight", welterweight and middleweight into one category called "middleweight", and light heavyweight and heavyweight into one category called "heavyweight."

Facial damage was coded by a research assistant, coding each facial photograph for marks of possible damage (e.g., broken nose, cauliflower ear, scarring) using binary coding (0 = damage absent; 1 = damage present).

The age (in years) and sex (male = 0, female = 1) of the US-based MTurkers will also be collected.

In line with the original study, a "facial shape" variable will be represented by multiple PCA (i.e., principal components analysis) scores, described in further detail in the analysis plan section.

The details of our "facial shape" variable is detailed in the analysis plan section, wherein geometric morphometric analyses are used to create the PCA scores required for the "facial shape" variable.

Each participant’s ratings on perceived aggressiveness and fighting ability will be converted to z scores to account for differences in scale use, and a mean standardized score will be calculated for each photograph.

Similar to the original study, we will combine flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight and lightweight divisions into one category called "lightweight", welterweight and middleweight into one category called "middleweight", and light heavyweight and heavyweight into one category called "heavyweight."

Our statistical analyses will follow that of Třebický et al. (2013).  Associations between variables will be assessed by Pearson's correlation provided that the data are normally distributed, or Pearson's correlation with bootstrapping with 10,000 iterations or Kendall's test for ordinal data if the data are not normally distributed.  We will first test the relation between potentially confounding variables.  A correlation will be run between fighter's age and perceived aggressiveness, and perceived fighting ability; and then the correlations between male and female judgments of aggressiveness and fighting ability.  We will then run a correlation between perceived aggressiveness and perceived fighting ability.

A correlation will then be run between perceived aggressiveness and fighting success, as well as perceived fighting ability and fighting success.  Linear regression analyses will also be run with perceived fighting ability as a predictor, fighting success as the criterion, and age as a covariate.

Correlations will then be run between perceived aggressiveness and weight, and perceived fighting ability and weight.  Two linear regressions will then be run with weight as a covariate in both analyses, fighting success as a predictor in both analyses, and each perception variable as a criterion in separate analyses (i.e., perceived aggressiveness in one linear regression, and perceived fighting ability in the other).  We will then run an additional regression with weight, number of wins, and the interaction between weight and the numbers of wins.  In the original study, this was done to compare which of the two previous analyses held a better fit.

A linear regression will then be run with perceived fighting ability as the criterion, and weight and fighting success as predictors.  Then, a one-way ANOVA will be performed with perceived fighting ability as the dependent variable and weight category as the independent variable.  Pairwise comparisons (least significance difference) will be run on weight category to examine the differences between light, middle, and heavyweight fighters.

A correlation will then be run between perceived fighting ability and actual fighting success for the individual light, middle, and heavyweight categories.  A correlation will then be run between facial damage and perceived fighting ability and aggressiveness.

Landmark data will be imported into R, and will be analysed using the "geomorph" package.  First, semi-landmarks will be identified using the "define.sliders" function.  Factoring in the semi-landmark data generated from the previous function, a generalised Procrustes analysis will be conducted on the landmark data using the "gpagen" function.  After which, a principal components analysis will be conducted on the shape coordinates using the "plotTangentSpace" function where, in line with the original study, we will retain all of the principal components and use them for further analyses.  This will be referred to as the facial shape variable.

We will then use the "procD.lm" function to perform a series of Procrustes ANOVAs with 9,999 permutations.  First, we will examine shape data (represented by multiple PCA scores) as the outcome variable, and perceived aggressiveness as an explanatory variable.  We will then perform an additional, similar Procrustes ANOVA, but now controlling for weight.  We will then test for the interaction between weight and perceived aggressiveness; thus, we will include both the main effects of weight and perceived aggressiveness, as well as the interaction between the two variables, with facial shape as the outcome variable.  We will then examine the same effect for both heavyweights and lightweights, separately; that is, we will run separately analyses for heavyweights and lightweights, with facial shape as the outcome variable and perceived aggressiveness as the explanatory variable.  We will then employ another Procrustes ANOVA to examine fighting success on facial shape, controlling for weight; and then run the same analysis for both heavyweights and lightweights, in that we will examine fighting success on facial shape in both groups.  In an extension of the original study, we will then run the same analyses but with perceived fighting ability as an explanatory variable.

In line with the original study, we will then use tpsRegr (Version 1.45) to visualise the results of the shape data.  Using thin-plate spline deformation grids in tpsRegr, we will visualise the shape data on perceived aggressiveness based on the results of all fighters (split into low, average, and high aggressive, represented as one deviation below and above the mean, as per the original study), magnified by three times for visibility purposes.  We will then visualise the shape data on fighting success in heavyweight fighters using thin-plate spline-deformation grids (split into low, average, and high fighting success, as per the original study), again magnified by three times for visibility purposes.  These deformation grids will be accompanied by composite visualisations created in tpsSuper (Version 2.05).  In an extension of the original study, we will visualise the shape data on perceived fighting ability in the entire sample, and then specifically for the heavyweight fighters, using thin-plate spline-deformation grids (split into low, average, and high perceived fighting ability, again represented by one standard deviation below and above the mean) accompanied by the composite visualisations.

q20.value:
Fighting success will be calculated as the total number of wins relative to the proportion of fights, as per the original article.  Weight category is drawn from the ufc.com website, as well as weight (measured in kilograms) and fighter's age (in years).  There are eight categories for male fighters in the UFC: flyweight (up to 56.7kg), bantamweight (up to 61.2kg), featherweight (up to 65.8kg), lightweight (up to 70.3kg); welterweight (up to 77.1kg), middleweight (up to 83.9kg); light heavyweight (up to 93.0kg), and heavyweight (up to 120.2kg).  Similar to the original study, we will combine flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight and lightweight divisions into one category called "lightweight" (coded as "0"), welterweight and middleweight into one category called "middleweight" (coded as "1"), and light heavyweight and heavyweight into one category called "heavyweight" (coded as "2").

Facial damage was coded by a research assistant, coding each facial photograph for marks of possible damage (e.g., broken nose, cauliflower ear, scarring) using binary coding (0 = damage absent; 1 = damage present).

A "facial shape" variable will be represented by multiple PCA (i.e., principal components analysis) scores, described in further detail in the previous analysis plan section.

The coding scheme for our exclusion criteria of beards and moustaches is described below, in the data exclusion section.

q21.value: Two-tailed tests will be used for all of the analyses, and the p-value cut-off will be .05.

q22.value:
Consistent with the original study, no statistical outliers will be excluded from our analyses.  No awareness check will be used.  However, to be consistent with the original study, we have excluded MMA fighters from our analyses (and from being presented to MTurk participants) if they were female, had no photograph, those of perceivably African or Asian origin, those not facing directly into the camera, and those whose face was obscured by their hair.

Třebický et al. also excluded moustached and bearded fighters, but beards and moustaches themselves might not obstruct facial landmarking (e.g., stubble, pencil moustache).  To this end, two independent research assistants experienced in tpsDig2 facial landmarking techniques coded these faces on moustache and beardedness, where: 1 = no beard (i.e., clean shaven, stubble), 2 = some beard (i.e., slight beard, but deemed appropriate for facial landmarking); 3 = full beard (inappropriate for facial landmarking); and 4 = moustache (inappropriate for facial landmarking).  Agreement between the two research assistants was above 90% (i.e., in 675 out of 715 cases).  The remaining cases were discussed and categorised, and fighters whose beards and moustaches were deemed as an obstruction to the accurate placement of facial landmarks were excluded.  After Třebický et al.’s exclusion criteria were applied, our final dataset comprised 387 photographs from 715 facial portraits of UFC fighters from ufc.com and/or espn.com.

q23.value: Missing data will be dealt with using pairwise deletion.

q24.value: In line with the original study, we will then use tpsRegr (Version 1.45) to visualise the results of the shape data.  Using thin-plate spline deformation grids in tpsRegr, we will visualise the shape data on perceived aggressiveness based on the results of all fighters, magnified by three times for visibility purposes.  We will then visualise the shape data on fighting success in heavyweight fighters using thin-plate spline-deformation grids, again magnified by three times for visibility purposes.  We will then perform similar analyses for perceived fighting ability in the overall sample, and then only for the heavyweight fighters.  These deformation grids will be accompanied by composite visualisations created in tpsSuper (Version 2.05).  These might be considered exploratory analyses, as this analysis examines the features of the face associated with perceived aggressiveness or fighting success.
